ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot about human diversity and how lifestyle can affect hormones and behavior. It was a really interesting course, and I feel like I'm now better equipped to read social science research with a critical eye, especially when it comes to making world-wide conclusions based on one group of people.
We learned about the role of several hormones on human behavior and how these interactions are often noisy and complex due to human variation.
I learned a lot about the biologically relevant hormones in humans and human interactions. I have a STEM background and still found the course very relevant and interesting.
Knowledge of how hormones influence our daily life via conclusions from scientific studies

how to look at studies critically
everything about hormones

Natural selection, evolution, behavior, life history theory, hormone evolution/function, fieldwork, human variation, brain's organizational effects, maternal/paternal behavior, sex, gender, libido, pair bonding, depression, competition, hunger/satiety, risk tolerance, and real-world applications.
Interesting material. Pretty fun.
Understanding of hormones and how they affect our behavior.

I learned all about hormones and life history traits. You learn in this class what an impact hormones have on your body and your life. I learned about the incredible variation in human endocrinology and how that manifests, and I feel like I learned practical tools about how to approach conversations about hormones like testosterone that are so commonly misunderstood.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course is very nicely laid out and paced. It doesn't feel too fast or too slow, and the grading is fair.
The main strength of this course is how we were fairly assessed. Many exam questions came from worksheets, which were really helpful when studying for exams.
Honestly, some of the questions in the worksheets and tests seem too open-ended / could refer to many of the studies in the readings.
Prof bribiescas cares a lot about the material and his students. Not a stressful or competitive environment, lots of class collaboration.

strengths: everything. Amazing prof, amazing topic, lectures were fun, guest lectures were cool
weaknesses: nothing. favorite class at yale

Strengths: Cool material. Prof is fun.
Weaknesses: Rote memorization based.

Strengths: straightforward course content and assignments, interesting content
Weaknesses: none

Professor Bribiescas is a total strength. Super knowledgeable, kind, and just generally a good lecturer. I found classes really interesting, he was flexible when students had issues, and the exams were reasonable. 

This is a classic good, interesting, and not too challenging class. I enjoyed every lecture and I will miss Professor Bribiescas.

Weaknesses: None. He got rid of section which was great!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes
This is a very manageable yet interesting course, so I would recommend it to really anyone, regardless of their major.
Absolutely yes! The course is low-stress and really interesting.

Yeah, Bribiescas is a great Professor and is clearly passionate about teaching. The open-book tests made it so much less stressful. Overall, it made it so I focused more on understanding the questions and material rather than the rote memorization of random facts. I would take it as a fifth credit or just for fun. I do wish the Prof. allowed iPads / computer notes given a tree was killed per exam.
Yes! I find myself talking about what I learned very frequently and making connections to my daily life, definitely good information to learn as human beings

YES. yes. yes. 1000 times yes. Please take this course. This should be a required course for everyone. Also, Dr. Bribiescas is probably one of the best lecturers at Yale. If you can take one of his classes before you graduate you won't regret it. Also, he made the tests open note this semester which took all the pressure off of "grades" so it really was just about learning the super interesting content. Take this class. Take it. You gotta take it.
Nice course. Hope it can be a science credit.
Absolutely! A great course for people who aren't super STEM inclined but are interested in science and human behavior. Would especially recommend for cog sci and psyc majors.

Prof Bribiescas rocks!! Hes not wild and crazy, hes a clear, calm, lecturer, but he absolutely loves what he is teaching. You can hear the excitement in his voice as he talks about hormones and life history theory. If you are interested in that sort of thing, totally take this class. Very pop sciency in a good way. Hes nice in office hours and it was great without section! Finally, he is really good about being respectful and cognizant of the tricky issues around hormones, sex, gender, etc. For example, he is VERY vigilant about the use of male and female rather than man and woman so as to not conflate sex and gender and devotes class time to discussions around the spectrum of gender identities, how sex manifests, etc. Also, he brought in a fantastic guest lecturer for the pregnancy day. Very cool!
